checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
OpenSlide is an open-source suite of tools written in C for reading, processing, and converting whole-slide pathology images (WSI) in various formats like SVS and TIFF.

The software is used for Objective 1: Build a unified latent space for cells, spatial spots and WSIs - specifically for preprocessing and handling gigapixel whole-slide histopathology images before they are fed into the pathology foundation model training pipeline.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation.

checks.name: Restricted Entities Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
OpenSlide is maintained by the OpenSlide project community with primary development contributions from Carnegie Mellon University and the University of Pittsburgh; the current maintainer is Benjamin Gilbert (affiliated with Carnegie Mellon University, LinkedIn not publicly listed in official documentation).

The entity is from a non-D5 country.

checks.notes:

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
Ollama is an open-source tool that enables easy local deployment and running of large language models (LLMs) like Llama, Gemma, DeepSeek, and Qwen on personal computers.

The software is used for Objective 2: Demonstrate clinical utility in diagnosis, risk stratification, and therapy prioritization - specifically for deploying and running the medical-report LLM that generates structured diagnostic summaries and clinical reports from pathology data.

Aligns with the approved research topic Datascience & engineering.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation.

checks.name: Restricted Entities Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
Ollama is owned and maintained by Ollama Inc., with primary developers including Jeffrey Morgan (Co-founder, LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/jmorganca) and Michael Chiang (Co-founder, LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/mxyng).

The entity and maintainers are from non-D5 country.

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
Transformers is an open-source library providing pre-trained models and tools for natural language processing, computer vision, and multimodal AI tasks, enabling researchers to build, train, and deploy state-of-the-art machine learning models.

The software is used for both Objective 1 (Build a unified latent space for cells, spatial spots and WSIs) and Objective 2 (Demonstrate clinical utility in diagnosis, risk stratification and therapy prioritization) - serving as the core model library for constructing the single-cell foundation model, pathology foundation model, and medical report generation LLM architectures.

Aligns with approved research topics Datascience & engineering

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation.

checks.name: Restricted Entities Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
Transformers is owned and maintained by Hugging Face Inc., with primary maintainers including Sylvain Gugger (Research Engineer, LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/sylvain-gugger), Lysandre Debut (Machine Learning Engineer, LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/lysandre-debut), and Thomas Wolf (Co-founder & CSO, LinkedIn: linkedin.com/in/thomas-wolf-a056857).

The entity is from non-D5 country.

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
TCGA contains whole-slide pathology images (H&E stained), genomic profiles (DNA sequencing, copy number variations), transcriptomic data (RNA-seq, miRNA-seq), clinical annotations, proteomic data (RPPA), and molecular subtyping information across 33 cancer types from over 20,000 samples.

The dataset is used for both Objective 1 (Build a unified latent space for cells, spatial spots and WSIs) and Objective 2 (Demonstrate clinical utility in diagnosis, risk stratification and therapy prioritization) - specifically for training and evaluating the pathology foundation model and multimodal diagnostic model on large-scale whole-slide images paired with genomic and clinical data.

Aligns with the approved research topic Bioscience.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation.

checks.name: Restricted Entities Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
TCGA is owned and maintained by the National Cancer Institute (NCI) and the National Human Genome Research Institute (NHGRI), both part of the National Institutes of Health (NIH), U.S. Department of Health and Human Services; current data management is handled by the Genomic Data Commons (GDC) at the Center for Translational Data Science, University of Chicago (no individual LinkedIn profiles available as this is a large institutional consortium).

The entity is from non-D5 country.

checks.name: Prompts / Fine-tuning Scripts
checks.notes: No prompts and fine-tuning scripts have been provided.

checks.name: Sample Inspection
checks.notes: 30 random images from TCGA project were downloaded as SVS files, converted to PNG files and visually inspected. All these images were histopathology slides.

checks.name: Provenance
checks.notes: TCGA was originally created by NCI and NHGRI in a joint effort launched in 2006 (pilot phase) with expansion to Phase II in 2009, involving multiple genome characterization centers (Broad Institute, Harvard, UNC, MD Anderson, Baylor, BCGSC, Van Andel) and sequencing centers; the current maintainer is NCI's Genomic Data Commons (GDC) at the University of Chicago, which provides the centralized data portal and harmonized datasets.

checks.name: License / Permissions
checks.notes:
TCGA operates under a two-tier government data sharing framework, Open Access Tier and Controlled Access Tier. 
The requested datasets are from Open Access Tier:
Permissions (Open Access Tier):

Free access to de-identified clinical and biospecimen data without user certification
Can use for research purposes including publications and presentations
Can download and analyze genomic data that cannot identify individuals
Available for academic, non-profit, and commercial research

Restrictions (All Data):

Must comply with TCGA Responsible Use Policy and Publication Guidelines
Must provide proper attribution and citation in publications
Cannot attempt to re-identify individual participants
Must provide annual progress updates on data use
Controlled Access data requires dbGaP authorization and Data Use Certification
Cannot redistribute molecular analytes or tissue materials
Must destroy datasets upon project completion or transfer (unless approved)
Commercial use may require additional permissions beyond research use
Access can be revoked immediately if terms are violated

checks.name: Project & Usage Alignment
checks.notes:
CELLxGENE Census contains standardized single-cell RNA transcriptomics data (count matrices of tens of millions of cells by >60k genes) from human and mouse tissues across hundreds of publicly available studies, with standardized cell metadata (cell type, tissue, sequencing technology, donor ID) and gene metadata (GENCODE-based IDs and gene names).

The dataset is used for Objective 1: Build a unified latent space for cells, spatial spots and WSIs, specifically for pretraining the modality-specific single-cell RNA-seq encoder as part of the multimodal foundation model.

Aligns with approved research topic Bioscience.

checks.name: Prohibited Use Screening (LC 2.7)
checks.notes: No mention of sensitive terms in the documentation.

checks.name: Restricted Entities Screening (LC 2.5)
checks.notes:
The dataset is owned and maintained by Chan Zuckerberg Initiative Foundation (http://www.chanzuckerberg.com/); key team leaders include Jonah Cool (Program Officer, Single-Cell Biology Program, linkedin.com/in/not-found-in-search) and Ambrose Carr (Director of Product Management, linkedin.com/in/ambrosejcarr).

The entity is from non-D5 country.

checks.name: Prompts / Fine-tuning Scripts
checks.notes: No prompts or user files provided.

checks.name: Sample Inspection
checks.notes: Low risk. Skipping inspection.

checks.name: Provenance
checks.notes: The dataset was created by the CZI Cell Science Program team led by Arathi Mani, Jonah Cool, and Ambrose Carr; current maintainer is Chan Zuckerberg Initiative Foundation with ongoing curation by the CZI Single-Cell Biology Program team.

checks.name: License / Permissions
checks.notes:
CC BY 4.0 License:

Free to use for commercial, research, and educational purposes
Can modify, distribute, and create derivatives
Can integrate into proprietary applications
Must provide attribution to original authors and CZI
Must indicate if changes were made
Must not attempt re-identification of de-identified individuals

observations: Multiple models have been mentioned but there is no way to access and assess them.
recommendation: Conditional to the information on the models provided, recommended for grand challenge.
